doc.summary: Creates a number with the value exponent*2^mantissa (significand).
doc.param: Desired value for the mantissa.
Desired value for the exponent.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Create(System.Int32,System.Int32)
doc.summary: Creates a number with the value exponent*2^mantissa (significand).
doc.param: Desired value for the mantissa.
Desired value for the exponent.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.CreateNaN(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary: Creates a not-a-number arbitrary-precision binary float.
doc.param: A number to use as diagnostic information associated with this object. If none is needed, should be zero.
doc.returns: A quiet not-a-number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.CreateNaN(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Creates a not-a-number arbitrary-precision binary float.
doc.param: A number to use as diagnostic information associated with this object. If none is needed, should be zero.
Whether the return value will be signaling (true) or quiet (false).
Whether the return value is negative.

An arithmetic context to control the precision (in bits) of the diagnostic information. The rounding and exponent range of this context will be ignored. Can be null. The only flag that can be signaled in this context is FlagInvalid, which happens if diagnostic information needs to be truncated and too much memory is required to do so.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivRemNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)
doc.summary: Calculates the quotient and remainder using the DivideToIntegerNaturalScale and the formula in RemainderNaturalScale.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.
doc.returns: A 2 element array consisting of the quotient and remainder in that order.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivRemNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Calculates the quotient and remainder using the DivideToIntegerNaturalScale and the formula in RemainderNaturalScale.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.

An arithmetic context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. This context will be used only in the division portion of the remainder calculation; as a result, it's possible for the remainder to have a higher precision than given in this context. Flags will be set on the given context only if the context's HasFlags is true and the integer part of the division result doesn't fit the precision and exponent range without rounding. Can be null, in which the precision is unlimited and no additional rounding, other than the rounding down to an integer after division, is needed.
doc.returns: A 2 element array consisting of the quotient and remainder in that order.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Divide(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)
doc.summary: Divides this object by another binary float and returns the result. When possible, the result will be exact.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two numbers. Returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Returns NaN if the result can't be exact because it would have a nonterminating binary expansion.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Divide(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides this arbitrary-precision binary float by another arbitrary-precision binary float. The preferred exponent for the result is this object's exponent minus the divisor's exponent.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and no rounding is needed.
doc.returns:
The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0; or, either
is null or
's precision is 0, and the result would have a nonterminating binary expansion; or, the rounding mode is ERounding.None and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideAndRemainderNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)
doc.summary: Calculates the quotient and remainder using the DivideToIntegerNaturalScale and the formula in RemainderNaturalScale.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.
doc.returns: A 2 element array consisting of the quotient and remainder in that order.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideAndRemainderNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Calculates the quotient and remainder using the DivideToIntegerNaturalScale and the formula in RemainderNaturalScale.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.

An arithmetic context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. This context will be used only in the division portion of the remainder calculation; as a result, it's possible for the remainder to have a higher precision than given in this context. Flags will be set on the given context only if the context's HasFlags is true and the integer part of the division result doesn't fit the precision and exponent range without rounding. Can be null, in which the precision is unlimited and no additional rounding, other than the rounding down to an integer after division, is needed.
doc.returns: A 2 element array consisting of the quotient and remainder in that order.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision binary floats, and gives a particular exponent to the result.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.

The desired exponent. A negative number places the cutoff point to the right of the usual radix point (so a negative number means the number of binary digit places to round to). A positive number places the cutoff point to the left of the usual radix point.

An arithmetic context object to control the rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value. If the precision given in the context is other than 0, calls the Quantize method with both arguments equal to the result of the operation (and can signal FlagInvalid and return NaN if the result doesn't fit the given precision). If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the context defines an exponent range and the desired exponent is outside that range. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is ERounding.None and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision binary floats, and gives a particular exponent to the result.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.

The desired exponent. A negative number places the cutoff point to the right of the usual radix point (so a negative number means the number of binary digit places to round to). A positive number places the cutoff point to the left of the usual radix point.
The rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Returns NaN if the rounding mode is ERounding.None and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,System.Int64,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision binary floats, and gives a particular exponent to the result.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.

The desired exponent. A negative number places the cutoff point to the right of the usual radix point (so a negative number means the number of binary digit places to round to). A positive number places the cutoff point to the left of the usual radix point.

An arithmetic context object to control the rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value. If the precision given in the context is other than 0, calls the Quantize method with both arguments equal to the result of the operation (and can signal FlagInvalid and return NaN if the result doesn't fit the given precision). If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the context defines an exponent range and the desired exponent is outside that range. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is ERounding.None and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,System.Int64,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision binary floats, and gives a particular exponent to the result.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.

The desired exponent. A negative number places the cutoff point to the right of the usual radix point (so a negative number means the number of binary digit places to round to). A positive number places the cutoff point to the left of the usual radix point.
The rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is ERounding.None and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideToIntegerNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision binary floats, and returns the integer part of the result, rounded down, with the preferred exponent set to this value's exponent minus the divisor's exponent.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float to divide by.
doc.returns: The integer part of the quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideToIntegerNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides this object by another object, and returns the integer part of the result (which is initially rounded down), with the preferred exponent set to this value's exponent minus the divisor's exponent.
doc.param: The number to divide by.

An arithmetic context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the integer part of the result. Flags will be set on the given context only if the context's HasFlags is true and the integer part of the result doesn't fit the precision and exponent range without rounding. Can be null, in which the precision is unlimited and no additional rounding, other than the rounding down to an integer after division, is needed.
doc.returns: The integer part of the quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the return value would overflow the exponent range. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is ERounding.None and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideToIntegerZeroScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides this object by another object, and returns the integer part of the result, with the exponent set to 0.
doc.param: The number to divide by.

An arithmetic context object to control the precision. The rounding and exponent range settings of this context are ignored. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited.
doc.returns: The integer part of the quotient of the two objects. The exponent will be set to 0. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0, or if the result doesn't fit the given precision.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.DivideToSameExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Divides this object by another binary float and returns a result with the same exponent as this object (the dividend).
doc.param: The number to divide by.
The rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two numbers. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is ERounding.None and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Equals(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)

doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float.
doc.returns: true if this object's mantissa (significand) and exponent are equal to those of another object; otherwise, false .

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Equals(System.Object)
doc.summary: Determines whether this object's mantissa (significand), exponent, and properties are equal to those of another object and that other object is an arbitrary-precision binary float. Not-a-number values are considered equal if the rest of their properties are equal.
doc.param:
The parameter
is an arbitrary object.
doc.returns: true if the objects are equal; otherwise, false .

doc.returns: true if this object's mantissa (significand) and exponent are equal to those of another object; otherwise, false .

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Exp(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds e (the base of natural logarithms) raised to the power of this object's value.
doc.param:
An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
This parameter can't be null, as the exponential function's results are generally not exact.
(Unlike in the General Binary Arithmetic Specification, any rounding mode is allowed.).
doc.returns:
Exponential of this object. If this object's value is 1, returns an approximation to " e" within the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter
is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.param:
The parameter

doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.FromString(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Creates a binary float from a text string that represents a number. Note that if the string contains a negative exponent, the resulting value might not be exact, in which case the resulting binary float will be an approximation of this decimal number's value.
The format of the string generally consists of:
An optional plus sign ("+" , U+002B) or minus sign ("-", U+002D) (if '-' , the value is negative.)
One or more digits, with a single optional decimal point after the first digit and before the last digit.
Optionally, "E+"/"e+" (positive exponent) or "E-"/"e-" (negative exponent) plus one or more digits specifying the exponent.
The string can also be "-INF", "-Infinity", "Infinity", "INF", quiet NaN ("NaN") followed by any number of digits, or signaling NaN ("sNaN") followed by any number of digits, all in any combination of upper and lower case.
All characters mentioned above are the corresponding characters in the Basic Latin range. In particular, the digits must be the basic digits 0 to 9 (U+0030 to U+0039). The string is not allowed to contain white space characters, including spaces.
doc.param:
The parameter
is a text string.

A zero-based index showing where the desired portion of
begins.

The length, in code units, of the desired portion of
(but not more than
's length).
A precision context specifying the precision, rounding, and exponent range (in bits) to apply to the parsed number. Can be null.
doc.returns: The parsed number, converted to arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.param: The number to convert as a 16-bit unsigned integer.
doc.returns: This number's value as an arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Log(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the natural logarithm of this object, that is, the power (exponent) that e (the base of natural logarithms) must be raised to in order to equal this object's value.
doc.param:
An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
This parameter can't be null, as the ln function's results are generally not exact.
(Unlike in the General Binary Arithmetic Specification, any rounding mode is allowed.).
doc.returns:
Ln(this object). Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object is less than 0 (the result would be a complex number with a real part equal to Ln of this object's absolute value and an imaginary part equal to pi, but the return value is still NaN.). Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter
is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0). Signals no flags and returns negative infinity if this object's value is 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Log10(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the base-10 logarithm of this object, that is, the power (exponent) that the number 10 must be raised to in order to equal this object's value.
doc.param:
An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
This parameter can't be null, as the ln function's results are generally not exact.
(Unlike in the General Binary Arithmetic Specification, any rounding mode is allowed.).
doc.returns:
Ln(this object)/Ln(10). Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if this object is less than 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter
is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.MultiplyAndAdd(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Multiplies by one value, and then adds another value.

The value to add.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and rounding isn't needed. If the precision doesn't indicate a simplified arithmetic, rounding and precision/exponent adjustment is done only once, namely, after multiplying and adding.
doc.returns: The result thisValue * multiplicand + augend.

If the precision doesn't indicate a simplified arithmetic, rounding and precision/exponent adjustment is done only once, namely, after multiplying and subtracting.

An arithmetic context object to control the precision and exponent range of the result. The rounding mode from this context is ignored. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).

has an unlimited exponent range.

doc.summary: Finds the constant , the circumference of a circle divided by its diameter.
doc.param:
An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
This parameter can't be null, as can never be represented exactly.
.

is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Plus(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Rounds this object's value to a given precision, using the given rounding mode and range of exponent, and also converts negative zero to positive zero.
doc.param: A context for controlling the precision, rounding mode, and exponent range. Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and rounding isn't needed.
doc.returns:
The closest value to this object's value, rounded to the specified precision. Returns the same value as this object if
is null or the precision and exponent range are unlimited.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.PositiveInfinity
doc.summary: Positive infinity, greater than any other number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Pow(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Raises this object's value to the given exponent.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision binary float expressing the exponent to raise this object's value to.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and rounding isn't needed.
doc.returns:
This^exponent. Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object and exponent are both 0; or if this value is less than 0 and the exponent either has a fractional part or is infinity. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter
is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0), and the exponent has a fractional part.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Pow(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Raises this object's value to the given exponent.
doc.param: The exponent to raise this object's value to.
doc.returns: This^exponent. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if this object and exponent are both 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Pow(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Raises this object's value to the given exponent.
doc.param: The exponent to raise this object's value to.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and rounding isn't needed.
doc.returns: This^exponent. Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object and exponent are both 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Precision
doc.summary: Finds the number of digits in this number's mantissa (significand). Returns 1 if this value is 0, and 0 if this value is infinity or not-a-number (NaN).
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Quantize(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but with the same exponent as another binary float.
Note that this is not always the same as rounding to a given number of binary digit places, since it can fail if the difference between this value's exponent and the desired exponent is too big, depending on the maximum precision. If rounding to a number of binary digit places is desired, it's better to use the RoundToExponent and RoundToIntegral methods instead.
Remark: This method can be used to implement fixed-point binary arithmetic, in which a fixed number of digits come after the radix point. A fixed-point binary arithmetic in which no digits come after the radix point (a desired exponent of 0) is considered an "integer arithmetic".
doc.param: A binary float containing the desired exponent of the result. The mantissa (significand) is ignored. The exponent is the number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the sixteenth (10b^-3, 0.0001b), and 3 means round to the sixteen-place (10b^3, 1000b). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

An arithmetic context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float with the same value as this object but with the exponent changed. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding, or if the arithmetic context defines an exponent range and the given exponent is outside that range.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Quantize(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.param: The desired exponent for the result. The exponent is the number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

An arithmetic context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float with the same value as this object but with the exponent changed. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if this object is infinity, if the rounded result can't fit the given precision, or if the context defines an exponent range and the given exponent is outside that range.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Quantize(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.param: The desired exponent for the result. The exponent is the number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

An arithmetic context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float with the same value as this object but with the exponent changed. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if this object is infinity, if the rounded result can't fit the given precision, or if the context defines an exponent range and the given exponent is outside that range.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Reduce(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Removes trailing zeros from this object's mantissa (significand). For example, 1.00 becomes 1.
If this object's value is 0, changes the exponent to 0.
doc.param: An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and rounding isn't needed.
doc.returns: This value with trailing zeros removed. Note that if the result has a very high exponent and the context says to clamp high exponents, there may still be some trailing zeros in the mantissa (significand).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Remainder(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the remainder that results when dividing two arbitrary-precision binary floats. The remainder is the value that remains when the absolute value of this object is divided by the absolute value of the other object; the remainder has the same sign (positive or negative) as this object's value.
doc.param: The number to divide by.

An arithmetic context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. This context will be used both in the division portion and in the remainder portion of the remainder calculation. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and no additional rounding (other than the rounding from integer division) is needed.
doc.returns: The remainder of the two numbers. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor is 0, or if the result doesn't fit the given precision.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RemainderNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)
doc.summary: Calculates the remainder of a number by the formula "this" - (("this" / "divisor") * "divisor") .
doc.param: The number to divide by.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RemainderNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Calculates the remainder of a number by the formula "this" - (("this" / "divisor") * "divisor").
doc.param: The number to divide by.

An arithmetic context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. This context will be used only in the division portion of the remainder calculation; as a result, it's possible for the return value to have a higher precision than given in this context. Flags will be set on the given context only if the context's HasFlags is true and the integer part of the division result doesn't fit the precision and exponent range without rounding. Can be null, in which the precision is unlimited and no additional rounding, other than the rounding down to an integer after division, is needed.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RemainderNear(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Finds the distance to the closest multiple of the given divisor, based on the result of dividing this object's value by another object's value.
If this and the other object divide evenly, the result is 0.
If the remainder's absolute value is less than half of the divisor's absolute value, the result has the same sign as this object and will be the distance to the closest multiple.
If the remainder's absolute value is more than half of the divisor' s absolute value, the result has the opposite sign of this object and will be the distance to the closest multiple.
If the remainder's absolute value is exactly half of the divisor's absolute value, the result has the opposite sign of this object if the quotient, rounded down, is odd, and has the same sign as this object if the quotient, rounded down, is even, and the result's absolute value is half of the divisor's absolute value.
This function is also known as the "IEEE Remainder" function.
doc.param: The number to divide by.

An arithmetic context object to control the precision. The rounding and exponent range settings of this context are ignored (the rounding mode is always treated as HalfEven). If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which the precision is unlimited.
doc.returns: The distance of the closest multiple. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor is 0, or either the result of integer division (the quotient) or the remainder wouldn't fit the given precision.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but rounded to a new exponent if necessary.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision. If the result can't fit the precision, additional digits are discarded to make it fit. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to the given exponent when rounding, and the given exponent is outside of the valid range of the arithmetic context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToExponent(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but rounded to a new exponent if necessary.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision. If the result can't fit the precision, additional digits are discarded to make it fit. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to the given exponent when rounding, and the given exponent is outside of the valid range of the arithmetic context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToExponentExact(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but rounded to the given exponent, and signals an inexact flag if the result would be inexact.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the arithmetic context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to the given exponent when rounding, and the given exponent is outside of the valid range of the arithmetic context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToExponentExact(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Returns a binary number with the same value as this object but rounded to the given exponent.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the eighth (10^-1, 1/8), and 3 means round to the eight (2^3, 8). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.
Desired mode for rounding this object's value.
doc.returns: A binary number rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToExponentExact(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, and signals an inexact flag if the result would be inexact.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the arithmetic context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to the given exponent when rounding, and the given exponent is outside of the valid range of the arithmetic context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToIntegerExact(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, and signals an inexact flag if the result would be inexact.
doc.param: An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float rounded to the closest integer representable in the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the arithmetic context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to 0 when rounding, and 0 is outside of the valid range of the arithmetic context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToIntegerNoRoundedFlag(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, without adding the FlagInexact or FlagRounded flags.
doc.param: An arithmetic context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags), except that this function will never add the FlagRounded and FlagInexact flags (the only difference between this and RoundToExponentExact). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float rounded to the closest integer representable in the given precision. If the result can't fit the precision, additional digits are discarded to make it fit. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to 0 when rounding, and 0 is outside of the valid range of the arithmetic context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToIntegralExact(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, and signals an inexact flag if the result would be inexact.
doc.param: An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float rounded to the closest integer representable in the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the arithmetic context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to 0 when rounding, and 0 is outside of the valid range of the arithmetic context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToIntegralNoRoundedFlag(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a binary float with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, without adding the FlagInexact or FlagRounded flags.
doc.param: An arithmetic context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags), except that this function will never add the FlagRounded and FlagInexact flags (the only difference between this and RoundToExponentExact). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A binary float rounded to the closest integer representable in the given precision. If the result can't fit the precision, additional digits are discarded to make it fit. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to 0 when rounding, and 0 is outside of the valid range of the arithmetic context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.RoundToPrecision(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Rounds this object's value to a given precision, using the given rounding mode and range of exponent.
doc.param: An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and no rounding is needed.
doc.returns:
The closest value to this object's value, rounded to the specified precision. Returns the same value as this object if
is null or the precision and exponent range are unlimited.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ScaleByPowerOfTwo(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary: Returns a number similar to this number but with the scale adjusted.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision integer.
doc.returns:
A number whose exponent is increased by
.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ScaleByPowerOfTwo(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a number similar to this number but with its scale adjusted.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns:
A number whose exponent is increased by
.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ScaleByPowerOfTwo(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Returns a number similar to this number but with the scale adjusted.

The parameter
is a 32-bit signed integer.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ScaleByPowerOfTwo(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a number similar to this number but with the scale adjusted.
doc.param:
The parameter
is a 32-bit signed integer.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Sign
doc.summary: Gets this value's sign: -1 if negative; 1 if positive; 0 if zero.
doc.value: This value's sign: -1 if negative; 1 if positive; 0 if zero.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.SignalingNaN
doc.summary: A not-a-number value that signals an invalid operation flag when it's passed as an argument to any arithmetic operation in arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Sqrt(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the square root of this object's value.
doc.param:
An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
This parameter can't be null, as the square root function's results are generally not exact for many inputs.
(Unlike in the General Binary Arithmetic Specification, any rounding mode is allowed.).
doc.returns:
The square root. Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object is less than 0 (the square root would be a complex number, but the return value is still NaN). Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter
is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.SquareRoot(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the square root of this object's value.
doc.param:
An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
This parameter can't be null, as the square root function's results are generally not exact for many inputs.
(Unlike in the General Binary Arithmetic Specification, any rounding mode is allowed.).
doc.returns:
The square root. Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object is less than 0 (the square root would be a complex number, but the return value is still NaN). Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter
is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.param: The number to subtract from this instance's value.
doc.returns: The difference of the two objects.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Subtract(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Subtracts an arbitrary-precision binary float from this instance.

An arithmetic context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and no rounding is needed.
doc.returns: The difference of the two objects.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Ten
doc.summary: Represents the number 10.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToByteChecked
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a byte (from 0 to 255) if it can fit in a byte (from 0 to 255) after truncating to an integer.
doc.returns: This number's value, truncated to a byte (from 0 to 255).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToByteIfExact
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a byte (from 0 to 255) if it can fit in a byte (from 0 to 255) without rounding to a different numerical value.
doc.returns: This number's value as a byte (from 0 to 255).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToByteUnchecked
doc.summary: Truncates this number's value to an integer and returns the least-significant bits of its two's-complement form as a byte (from 0 to 255).
doc.returns: This number, converted to a byte (from 0 to 255). Returns 0 if this value is infinity or not-a-number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToDouble

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToEIntegerExact
doc.summary: Converts this value to an arbitrary-precision integer, checking whether the value contains a fractional part.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToEIntegerIfExact
doc.summary: Converts this value to an arbitrary-precision integer, checking whether the value contains a fractional part.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToEngineeringString

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToExtendedDecimal

doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToInt16Checked
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a 16-bit signed integer if it can fit in a 16-bit signed integer after truncating to an integer.
doc.returns: This number's value, truncated to a 16-bit signed integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToInt16IfExact
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a 16-bit signed integer if it can fit in a 16-bit signed integer without rounding to a different numerical value.
doc.returns: This number's value as a 16-bit signed integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToInt32Unchecked

doc.returns: This number, converted to a 32-bit signed integer. Returns 0 if this value is infinity or not-a-number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToInt64Checked
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a 64-bit signed integer if it can fit in a 64-bit signed integer after truncating to an integer.
doc.returns: This number's value, truncated to a 64-bit signed integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToInt64IfExact
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a 64-bit signed integer if it can fit in a 64-bit signed integer without rounding to a different numerical value.
doc.returns: This number's value as a 64-bit signed integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToInt64Unchecked
doc.summary: Truncates this number's value to an integer and returns the least-significant bits of its two's-complement form as a 64-bit signed integer.
doc.returns: This number, converted to a 64-bit signed integer. Returns 0 if this value is infinity or not-a-number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToPlainString
doc.summary: Converts this value to a string, but without exponential notation.
doc.returns: A text string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToSByteChecked
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to an 8-bit signed integer if it can fit in an 8-bit signed integer after truncating to an integer.
doc.returns: This number's value, truncated to an 8-bit signed integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToSByteIfExact
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to an 8-bit signed integer if it can fit in an 8-bit signed integer without rounding to a different numerical value.
doc.returns: This number's value as an 8-bit signed integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToSByteUnchecked
doc.summary: Truncates this number's value to an integer and returns the least-significant bits of its two's-complement form as an 8-bit signed integer.
doc.returns: This number, converted to an 8-bit signed integer. Returns 0 if this value is infinity or not-a-number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToShortestString(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a string representation of this number's value after rounding to the given precision (using the given arithmetic context). If the number after rounding is neither infinity nor not-a-number (NaN), returns the shortest decimal form (in terms of nonzero decimal digits) of this number's value that results in the rounded number after the decimal form is converted to binary floating-point format (using the given arithmetic context).
doc.param: An arithmetic context to control precision (in bits), rounding, and exponent range of the rounded number. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null. If this parameter is null or defines no maximum precision, returns the same value as the ToString() method.
doc.returns: Shortest decimal form of this number's value for the given arithmetic context. The text string will be in exponential notation if the number's first nonzero decimal digit is more than five digits after the decimal point, or if the number's exponent is greater than 0 and its value is 10, 000, 000 or greater.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToSingle
doc.summary:
Converts this value to its closest equivalent as 32-bit floating-point number. The half-even rounding mode is used.
If this value is a NaN, sets the high bit of the 32-bit floating point number's significand area for a quiet NaN, and clears it for a signaling NaN. Then the other bits of the significand area are set to the lowest bits of this object's unsigned mantissa (significand), and the next-highest bit of the significand area is set if those bits are all zeros and this is a signaling NaN. Unfortunately, in the .NET implementation, the return value of this method may be a quiet NaN even if a signaling NaN would otherwise be generated.
doc.returns: The closest 32-bit binary floating-point number to this value. The return value can be positive infinity or negative infinity if this value exceeds the range of a 32-bit floating point number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToString
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a text string.
doc.returns: A string representation of this object. The value is converted to decimal and the decimal form of this number's value is returned. The text string will be in exponential notation if the converted number's scale is positive or if the number's first nonzero decimal digit is more than five digits after the decimal point.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToUInt16Checked
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a 16-bit unsigned integer if it can fit in a 16-bit unsigned integer after truncating to an integer.
doc.returns: This number's value, truncated to a 16-bit unsigned integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToUInt16IfExact
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a 16-bit unsigned integer if it can fit in a 16-bit unsigned integer without rounding to a different numerical value.
doc.returns: This number's value as a 16-bit unsigned integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToUInt16Unchecked
doc.summary: Truncates this number's value to an integer and returns the least-significant bits of its two's-complement form as a 16-bit unsigned integer.
doc.returns: This number, converted to a 16-bit unsigned integer. Returns 0 if this value is infinity or not-a-number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToUInt32Checked
doc.summary: Converts this number's value to a 32-bit signed integer if it can fit in a 32-bit signed integer after truncating to an integer.
doc.returns: This number's value, truncated to a 32-bit signed integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.ToUInt32IfExact

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Ulp
doc.summary: Returns the unit in the last place. The mantissa (significand) will be 1 and the exponent will be this number's exponent. Returns 1 with an exponent of 0 if this number is infinity or not-a-number (NaN).
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.op_Division(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat,PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)
doc.summary: Divides one binary float by another and returns the result. When possible, the result will be exact.
doc.param: The number that will be divided by the divisor.
The number to divide by.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two numbers. Returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Returns NaN if the result can't be exact because it would have a nonterminating binary expansion.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.op_Explicit(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)~System.Double
doc.summary:
Converts this value to its closest equivalent as a 64-bit floating-point number. The half-even rounding mode is used.
If this value is a NaN, sets the high bit of the 64-bit floating point number's significand area for a quiet NaN, and clears it for a signaling NaN. Then the other bits of the significand area are set to the lowest bits of this object's unsigned mantissa (significand), and the next-highest bit of the significand area is set if those bits are all zeros and this is a signaling NaN. Unfortunately, in the .NET implementation, the return value of this method may be a quiet NaN even if a signaling NaN would otherwise be generated.
doc.param: The value to convert to a 64-bit floating-point number.
doc.returns: The closest 64-bit floating-point number to this value. The return value can be positive infinity or negative infinity if this value exceeds the range of a 64-bit floating point number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.FromByte(System.Byte)
doc.summary: Converts a byte (from 0 to 255) to an arbitrary-precision integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.FromBytes(System.Byte[],System.Boolean)
doc.summary: Initializes an arbitrary-precision integer from an array of bytes.
doc.param:
A byte array consisting of the two's-complement form (see
"Forms of numbers"
) of the arbitrary-precision integer to create. The byte array is encoded using the following rules:
Positive numbers have the first byte's highest bit cleared, and negative numbers have the bit set.
The last byte contains the lowest 8-bits, the next-to-last contains the next lowest 8 bits, and so on. For example, the number 300 can be encoded as 0x01, 0x2C and 200 as 0x00, 0xC8 . (Note that the second example contains a set high bit in 0xC8 , so an additional 0 is added at the start to ensure it's interpreted as positive.)
To encode negative numbers, take the absolute value of the number, subtract by 1, encode the number into bytes, and toggle each bit of each byte. Any further bits that appear beyond the most significant bit of the number will be all ones. For example, the number -450 can be encoded as 0xfe, 0x70 and -52869 as 0xff, 0x31, 0x7B . (Note that the second example contains a cleared high bit in 0x31, 0x7B , so an additional 0xff is added at the start to ensure it's interpreted as negative.)
For little-endian, the byte order is reversed from the byte order just discussed.
.
If true, the byte order is little-endian, or least-significant-byte first. If false, the byte order is big-endian, or most-significant-byte first.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer. Returns 0 if the byte array's length is 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.FromRadixString(System.String,System.Int32)
doc.summary: Converts a string to an arbitrary-precision integer in a given radix.
doc.param: A string described by the FromRadixSubstring method.

A base from 2 to 36. Depending on the radix, the string can use the basic digits 0 to 9 (U+0030 to U+0039) and then the basic letters A to Z (U+0041 to U+005A). For example, 0-9 in radix 10, and 0-9, then A-F in radix 16.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer with the same value as the given string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.FromRadixSubstring(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
doc.summary: Converts a portion of a string to an arbitrary-precision integer in a given radix.
doc.param: A text string. The desired portion of the string must contain only characters allowed by the given radix, except that it may start with a minus sign ("-", U+002D) to indicate a negative number. The desired portion is not allowed to contain white space characters, including spaces.

A base from 2 to 36. Depending on the radix, the string can use the basic digits 0 to 9 (U+0030 to U+0039) and then the basic letters A to Z (U+0041 to U+005A). For example, 0-9 in radix 10, and 0-9, then A-F in radix 16.
The index of the string that starts the string portion.
The index of the string that ends the string portion. The length will be index + endIndex - 1.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer with the same value as given in the string portion.
doc.exception:
The parameter
is less than 0,
is less than 0, or either is greater than the string's length, or
is less than
.
The string portion is empty or in an invalid format.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.GetBits(System.Int32,System.Int32)
doc.summary: Retrieves bits from this integer's two' s-complement form.
doc.param: Zero-based index of the first bit to retrieve, where 0 is the least-significant bit of the number.
The number of bits to retrieve, starting with the first. Must be from 0 through 64.
doc.returns: A 64-bit signed integer containing the bits from this integer's two' s-complement form. The least significant bit is the first bit, and any unused bits are set to 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.GetDigitCount
doc.summary: Returns the number of decimal digits used by this integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.GetHashCode

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.GetLowBit

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.GetSignedBitLength
doc.summary: Finds the minimum number of bits needed to represent this object's value, except for its sign. If the value is negative, finds the number of bits in the value equal to this object's absolute value minus 1.
doc.returns: The number of bits in this object's value. Returns 0 if this object's value is 0 or negative 1.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.GetUnsignedBit(System.Int32)

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.GetUnsignedBitLength

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.GetUnsignedBitLengthAsEInteger

The remainder is the value that remains when the absolute value of this object is divided by the absolute value of the other object; the remainder has the same sign (positive or negative) as this object.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.ShiftLeft(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Returns an arbitrary-precision integer with the bits shifted to the left by a number of bits. A value of 1 doubles this value, a value of 2 multiplies it by 4, a value of 3 by 8, a value of 4 by 16, and so on.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.SqrtRem

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.ToRadixString(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Generates a string representing the value of this object, in the given radix.
doc.param: A radix from 2 through 36. For example, to generate a hexadecimal (base-16) string, specify 16. To generate a decimal (base-10) string, specify 10.
doc.returns: A string representing the value of this object. If this value is 0, returns "0". If negative, the string will begin with a minus sign ("-", U+002D). Depending on the radix, the string will use the basic digits 0 to 9 (U+0030 to U+0039) and then the basic letters A to Z (U+0041 to U+005A). For example, 0-9 in radix 10, and 0-9, then A-F in radix 16.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EInteger.ToString

doc.name: T:PeterO.Numbers.ERational
doc.summary:
Represents an arbitrary-precision rational number. This class can't be inherited. (The "E" stands for "extended", meaning that instances of this class can be values other than numbers proper, such as infinity and not-a-number.)
Thread safety: Instances of this class are immutable, so they are inherently safe for use by multiple threads. Multiple instances of this object with the same properties are interchangeable, so they should not be compared using the "==" operator (which might only check if each side of the operator is the same instance).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.#ctor(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary:
Initializes a new instance of the
class.
doc.param: The numerator.
The denominator.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.Abs
doc.summary: Returns the absolute value of this rational number, that is, a number with the same value as this one but as a nonnegative number.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision rational number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.Add(PeterO.Numbers.ERational)
doc.summary: Adds two rational numbers.
doc.param: Another arbitrary-precision rational number.
doc.returns: The sum of the two numbers. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if either operand is NaN.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.CompareTo(PeterO.Numbers.ERational)
doc.summary: Compares an arbitrary-precision rational number with this instance.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision rational number.
doc.returns: Zero if the values are equal; a negative number if this instance is less, or a positive number if this instance is greater.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.CompareToBinary(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)

doc.returns: Zero if the values are equal; a negative number if this instance is less, or a positive number if this instance is greater.

doc.summary: Compares an arbitrary-precision decimal number with this instance.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.
doc.returns: Zero if the values are equal; a negative number if this instance is less, or a positive number if this instance is greater.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.CompareToTotal(PeterO.Numbers.ERational)
doc.summary:
Compares the values of this object and another object, imposing a total ordering on all possible values. In this method:
For objects with the same value, the one with the higher denominator has a greater "absolute value".
Negative zero is less than positive zero.
Quiet NaN has a higher "absolute value" than signaling NaN. If both objects are quiet NaN or both are signaling NaN, the one with the higher diagnostic information has a greater "absolute value".
NaN has a higher "absolute value" than infinity.
Infinity has a higher "absolute value" than any finite number.
Negative numbers are less than positive numbers.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision rational number to compare with this one.
doc.returns: The number 0 if both objects have the same value, or -1 if this object is less than the other value, or 1 if this object is greater.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.CompareToTotalMagnitude(PeterO.Numbers.ERational)
doc.summary:
Compares the absolute values of this object and another object, imposing a total ordering on all possible values (ignoring their signs). In this method:
For objects with the same value, the one with the higher denominator has a greater "absolute value".
Negative zero and positive zero are considered equal.
Quiet NaN has a higher "absolute value" than signaling NaN. If both objects are quiet NaN or both are signaling NaN, the one with the higher diagnostic information has a greater "absolute value".
NaN has a higher "absolute value" than infinity.
Infinity has a higher "absolute value" than any finite number.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision rational number to compare with this one.
doc.returns: The number 0 if both objects have the same value, or -1 if this object is less than the other value, or 1 if this object is greater.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.CopySign(PeterO.Numbers.ERational)
doc.summary: Returns a number with the same value as this one, but copying the sign (positive or negative) of another number.
doc.param: A number whose sign will be copied.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision rational number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.FromString(System.String)
doc.summary:
Creates a rational number from a text string that represents a number. See
FromString(String, int, int) for more information.
doc.param: A string that represents a number.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision rational number with the same value as the given string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.FromString(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)

summary.para: Creates a rational number from a text string that represents a number.
The format of the string generally consists of:

list.item: An optional plus sign ("+" , U+002B) or minus sign ("-", U+002D) (if '-' , the value is negative.)
The numerator in the form of one or more digits.
Optionally, "/" followed by the denominator in the form of one or more digits. If a denominator is not given, it's equal to 1.

summary.para: The string can also be "-INF", "-Infinity", "Infinity", "INF", quiet NaN ("NaN" /"-NaN") followed by any number of digits, or signaling NaN ("sNaN" /"-sNaN") followed by any number of digits, all in any combination of upper and lower case.

All characters mentioned above are the corresponding characters in the Basic Latin range. In particular, the digits must be the basic digits 0 to 9 (U+0030 to U+0039). The string is not allowed to contain white space characters, including spaces.

doc.param: A text string, a portion of which represents a number.
A zero-based index that identifies the start of the number.
The length of the number within the string.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision rational number.

doc.summary: Converts a 16-bit unsigned integer to an arbitrary-precision rational number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.ToDecimal

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.ToDouble
doc.summary: Converts this value to a 64-bit floating-point number. The half-even rounding mode is used.
doc.returns: The closest 64-bit floating-point number to this value. The return value can be positive infinity or negative infinity if this value exceeds the range of a 64-bit floating point number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.ToEDecimal
doc.summary: Converts this rational number to a decimal number.
doc.returns: The exact value of the rational number, or not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't be exact because it has a nonterminating decimal expansion.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.ToEDecimal(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Converts this rational number to a decimal number and rounds the result to the given precision.
doc.param: An arithmetic context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and no rounding is needed.
doc.returns: The value of the rational number, rounded to the given precision. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if the context is null and the result can't be exact because it has a nonterminating decimal expansion.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.ERational.ToEDecimalExactIfPossible(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Converts this rational number to a decimal number, but if the result would have a nonterminating decimal expansion, rounds that result to the given precision.
doc.param: An arithmetic context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. This context will be used only if the exact result would have a nonterminating decimal expansion. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the precision is unlimited and no rounding is needed.
doc.returns: The exact value of the rational number if possible; otherwise,the rounded version of the result if a context is given. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if the context is null and the result can't be exact because it has a nonterminating decimal expansion.

doc.name: T:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding
doc.summary: Specifies the mode to use when "shortening" numbers that otherwise can't fit a given number of digits, so that the shortened number has about the same value. This "shortening" is known as rounding. (The "E" stands for "extended", and has this prefix to group it with the other classes common to this library, particularly EDecimal, EFloat, and ERational.).

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.Ceiling
doc.summary: If there is a fractional part, the number is rounded to the highest representable number that's closest to it.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.Down
doc.summary: The fractional part is discarded (the number is truncated).

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.Floor
doc.summary: If there is a fractional part, the number is rounded to the lowest representable number that's closest to it.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.HalfDown
doc.summary: Rounded to the nearest number; if the fractional part is exactly half, it is discarded.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.HalfEven
doc.summary: Rounded to the nearest number; if the fractional part is exactly half, the number is rounded to the closest representable number that is even. This is sometimes also known as "banker's rounding".

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.HalfUp
doc.summary: Rounded to the nearest number; if the fractional part is exactly half, the number is rounded to the closest representable number away from zero. This is the most familiar rounding mode for many people.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.None
doc.summary: Indicates that rounding will not be used. If rounding is required, the rounding operation will report an error.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.Odd
doc.summary: If there is a fractional part and the whole number part is even, the number is rounded to the closest representable odd number away from zero.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.OddOrZeroFiveUp
doc.summary: For binary floating point numbers, this is the same as Odd. For other bases (including decimal numbers), this is the same as ZeroFiveUp. This rounding mode is useful for rounding intermediate results at a slightly higher precision (at least 2 bits more for binary) than the final precision.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.Up
doc.summary: If there is a fractional part, the number is rounded to the closest representable number away from zero.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.ERounding.ZeroFiveUp
doc.summary: If there is a fractional part and if the last digit before rounding is 0 or half the radix, the number is rounded to the closest representable number away from zero; otherwise the fractional part is discarded. In overflow, the fractional part is always discarded.

doc.name: T:PeterO.Numbers.ETrapException
doc.summary: Exception thrown for arithmetic trap errors. (The "E" stands for "extended", and has this prefix to group it with the other classes common to this library, particularly EDecimal, EFloat, and ERational.).

doc.summary:

class.

A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

The parameter
is an arbitrary object.

doc.summary: Gets the arithmetic context used during the operation that triggered the trap. May be null.
doc.value: The arithmetic context used during the operation that triggered the trap. May be null.

doc.value: The flag that specifies the kind of error (EContext.FlagXXX). This will only be one flag, such as. FlagInexact or FlagSubnormal.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.ETrapException.Result
doc.summary: Gets the defined result of the operation that caused the trap.
doc.value: The defined result of the operation that caused the trap.
